climbs.name: Sidewinders
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Kelly Vaught, and Frank Bentwood, August 2003.

content.description:
This route begins on the right side of Diamondback Buttress' north face. The first pitch is great fun- the second pitch has some mandatory 5.7 R climbing, plus a punishing 10a offwidth.

Pitch 1: Lieback a flake (5.8) that slants up and left, then climb an interesting face past 5 bolts (10a above the last bolt) to the ledge and 2-bolt anchor shared with The Beast (130 feet).

Pitch 2: Climb a 5.9 crack that arches right (or the easier face further right), then lieback an unprotected corner (5.7 R) that leads to an awkward offwidth crack (5.10a). Belay at the base of the summit block.

Pitch 3: Climb the right side (west side) of the block, up an easy, juggy face, to a belay at a notch.

A short scramble leads to the summit where there's a 2-bolt anchor.

Descent: Scrable down the west side (toward Tahquitz Rock) to find the rappel bolts. A 100-foot rappel plus some 4th class downclimbing gets you down to the North Gully.

A Detailed topo of the route is included in the Best Climbs Tahquitz and Suicide guidebook.

climbs.name: The Beast
climbs.fa: Kelly Vaught, Bob Gaines, and Frank Bentwood, August 2003

content.description:
Pitch 1: Start in the middle of the north face of Diamonback Buttress, at a little left-slanting corner/overlap. Lieback/undercling the crack in the corner (5.10a), then climb a smooth slab past 6 bolts (5.11a above the fourth bolt), moving right at the top to a ledge with a 2-bolt anchor (130 feet).

Pitch 2: Climb the slab on the left past 2 bolts (5.11a) to a flake. Where the flake ends, a bolt protects face moves (5.10a) up to another crack. Follow this crack as it branches left, then peters out, where a sling on a horn protects easier face moves up to a ledge beneath the summit block.

Pitch 3: A bolt protects bouldery moves either left (5.11a) or straight up (height dependent 5.11, cheat stone optional). Either way, move left to an arete, where a hidden bolt on the left side of the arete protects the final slab moves to the unique summit where you'll find a 2-bolt anchor.

Descent: A short scramble down the west side of the summit block (toward Tahquitz Rock) leads to the rappel bolts. A 100-foot rappel, plus some 4th class downclimbing, gets you back down to the North Gully.

A Detailed topo of the route is included in the Best Climbs Tahquitz and Suicide guidebook.
